questions.text: A-30- year old HIV positive male who is on antiretroviral therapy (protease inhibitors) having pain in the right hip joint for 2 month. He has difficulty in abduction and internal rotation. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-Septic arthritis presents with high grade fever with hip pain and restricted movements. Option B-Osteochondritis is less commonly seen in hip joint. Option C-HIV patient on Protease inhibitors with hip pain,restricted abduction & internal rotation.The diagnosis is AVN due to Protease inhibitors. Option D-Tubercular arthritis can present with deformities like FABER,FADIR and shortening.

Correct Answer (D) Option A-Prolonged intake of steroids can cause ischemia to femoral head and ultimately will cause AVN. Option B-Sickle cell anemia can cause ischemia to femoral head due to obstruction by sickled RBCs and ultimately will cause AVN. Option C-Posterior dislocation hip can also cause disruption of blood supply resullting in AVN. Option D-therefore All of above can cause AVN of femur head.

questions.text: Most common cause of AVN of the hip is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) All options are the causes of AVN of head femur. But idiopathic is the M/C cause of AVN of the hip.

questions.text: Which of the following part of the bone is not prone for AVN?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Avascular necrosis (AVN), also known as osteonecrosis, is a condition resulting from the temporary or permanent loss of blood supply to a bone. This lack of blood flow causes the bone tissue to die, leading to collapse of the bone. The susceptibility of a bone part to AVN is largely dependent on its vascular supply, particularly if it relies on a few end-arteries with limited collateral circulation, making it vulnerable to ischemia if these vessels are damaged. The femoral neck (C) itself is generally not considered prone to AVN in the same way as its more distal counterpart, the femoral head. While fractures of the femoral neck can disrupt blood supply to the femoral head, leading to AVN of the head, the neck bone itself typically has a more robust blood supply from multiple arteries, making primary AVN of the neck itself less common. Let's examine why the other options are prone to AVN: A. Proximal scaphoid: The scaphoid bone in the wrist has a precarious blood supply, with the primary blood flow entering distally and then traveling proximally. The proximal pole of the scaphoid is particularly vulnerable to AVN if the blood supply is disrupted, typically due to a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid. This is why non-union and AVN are significant complications of scaphoid fractures. B. Body of talus: The talus bone in the ankle has a somewhat limited and tenuous blood supply, particularly to its body, which is mostly covered by articular cartilage and receives blood from various anastomosing arteries. Fractures of the talar neck or body can significantly disrupt this blood flow, making the body of the talus highly susceptible to AVN. D. Femoral head: The femoral head is highly susceptible to AVN. Its blood supply comes from several arteries that are vulnerable to disruption, especially after trauma (e.g., femoral neck fractures or dislocations of the hip). Non-traumatic causes like corticosteroid use or alcohol abuse also commonly lead to AVN of the femoral head due to impaired blood flow or cellular processes within the bone. The reliance on limited, terminal arteries makes it a classic site for AVN.

questions.text: In Avascular necrosis, investigation of choice is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-X-ray can detect changes at a late stage but once AVN is visible on Xray (i.e in late cases) , then MRI has no added advantage. Option B-MRI is superior to CT in cases of AVN. Option C-Bone scan is not done in cases of AVN. Option D-MRI is the IOC for AVN and it can detect AVN at the earliest.

questions.text: Avascular necrosis affects which part of femoral head?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anterolateral/ superolateral part of head femur is affected most by AVN.

questions.text: A 50- year-old man sustained posterior dislocation of left hip in an accident. Dislocation was reduced after 3 days. He started complaining of pain in left hip after 6 months .X- ray of the pelvis was normal. The most relevant investigation at the stage will be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-CRP Levels in blood is not diagnostic of AVN. Option B,C-Ultrasonography and Arthrography of hip are not superior to MRI to detect AVN at the earliest. Option D-Diagnosis here is of AVN and it is best/earliest picked by MRI.

choices.text: Stress fracture of neck of femur

questions.text: A 45 years old woman, known cause of pemphigus vulgaris on regular treatment with controlled primary disease presented with pain in the right hip and knee. Examination revealed no limb length discrepancy but the patient has tenderness in the scarpa’s triangle and limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the right hip joint as compared to the other side. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Stress fracture of neck of femur is uncommon. Option B-Limitation of abduction and internal rotation in a patient with a disease where he might be taking steroids such as pemphigus vulgaris, makes the diagnosis of AVN of femoral head. Always look in the question , if any disease is mentioned, examiner is indirectly giving a clue of long term steroid intake. Option C-Perthes disease occurs in 4-8 years age group. Option D-Transient synovitis of hip can present with fever.
